strings.description: Trim leading and trailing white-space from string

strings.body:
# shellcheck disable=SC2086,SC2048
trim_all() {
    # Usage: trim_all "   example   string    "
    set -f
    set -- $*
    printf '%s\n' "$*"
    set +f
}
strings.description: Trim all white-space from string and truncate spaces
Split a string on a delimiter
Strip all instances of pattern from string
Strip first occurrence of pattern from string
Strip pattern from start of string
Strip pattern from end of string

strings.body:
urlencode() {
    # Usage: urlencode "string"
    local LC_ALL=C
    for (( i = 0; i < ${#1}; i++ )); do
        : "\${1:i:1}"
        case "\$_" in
            [a-zA-Z0-9.~_-])
                printf '%s' "\$_"
            ;;

            *)
                printf '%%%02X' "'\$_"
            ;;
        esac
    done
    printf '\n'
}

case "\$var" in
    *sub_string*)
        # Do stuff
    ;;

    *sub_string2*)
        # Do more stuff
    ;;

    *)
        # Else
    ;;
esac
strings.description: Check if string contains a sub-string

strings.body:
if [[ \$var == sub_string* ]]; then
    printf '%s\n' "var starts with sub_string."
fi

# Inverse (var does not start with sub_string).
if [[ \$var != sub_string* ]]; then
    printf '%s\n' "var does not start with sub_string."
fi
strings.description: Check if string starts with sub-string

strings.body:
if [[ \$var == *sub_string ]]; then
    printf '%s\n' "var ends with sub_string."
fi

# Inverse (var does not end with sub_string).
if [[ \$var != *sub_string ]]; then
    printf '%s\n' "var does not end with sub_string."
fi
strings.description: Check if string ends with sub-string

arrays.body:
remove_array_dups() {
    # Usage: remove_array_dups "array"
    declare -A tmp_array

    for i in "$@"; do
        [[ \$i ]] && IFS=" " tmp_array["\${i:- }"]=1
    done

    printf '%s\n' "${!tmp_array[@]}"
}

loops.body:
# Loop from 0-100 (no variable support).
for i in {0..100}; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$i"
done
loops.description: Loop over a range of numbers

loops.body:
# Loop from 0-VAR.
VAR=50
for ((i=0;i<=VAR;i++)); do
    printf '%s\n' "\$i"
done
loops.description: Loop over a variable range of numbers

loops.body:
arr=(apples oranges tomatoes)

# Just elements.
for element in "${arr[@]}"; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$element"
done

arr=(apples oranges tomatoes)

# Elements and index.
for i in "${!arr[@]}"; do
    printf '%s\n' "${arr[i]}"
done

# Alternative method.
for ((i=0;i<${#arr[@]};i++)); do
    printf '%s\n' "${arr[i]}"
done
loops.description: Loop over an array with an index

loops.body:
while read -r line; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$line"
done < "file"
loops.description: Loop over the contents of a file

loops.body:
# Greedy example.
for file in *; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$file"
done

# PNG files in dir.
for file in ~/Pictures/*.png; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$file"
done

# Iterate over directories.
for dir in ~/Downloads/*/; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$dir"
done

# Brace Expansion.
for file in /path/to/parentdir/{file1,file2,subdir/file3}; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$file"
done

# Iterate recursively.
shopt -s globstar
for file in ~/Pictures/**/*; do
    printf '%s\n' "\$file"
done
shopt -u globstar

file handling.description: Read a file to a string

file handling.body:
# Bash <4 (discarding empty lines).
IFS=$'\n' read -d "" -ra file_data < "file"

# Bash <4 (preserving empty lines).
while read -r line; do
    file_data+=("\$line")
done < "file"

# Bash 4+
mapfile -t file_data < "file"
file handling.description: Read a file to an array (*by line*)
Get the first N lines of a file
Get the last N lines of a file
Get the number of lines in a file
Count files or directories in directory

file handling.body:
extract() {
    # Usage: extract file "opening marker" "closing marker"
    while IFS=$'\n' read -r line; do
        [[ \$extract && \$line != "\$3" ]] &&
            printf '%s\n' "\$line"

        [[ \$line == "\$2" ]] && extract=1
        [[ \$line == "\$3" ]] && extract=
    done < "\$1"
}

file paths.description: Get the directory name of a file path
Get the base-name of a file path

variables.body:
$ hello_world="value"
$ var="world"

# Declare a nameref.
$ declare -n ref=hello_\$var

$ printf '%s\n' "\$ref"
value
variables.description: Assign and access a variable using a variable
Name a variable based on another variable

arithmetic.body:
# Simple math
((var=1+2))

# Decrement/Increment variable
((var++))
((var--))
((var+=1))
((var-=1))

# Using variables
((var=var2*arr[2]))

# Set the value of var to var2 if var2 is greater than var.
# var: variable to set.
# var2>var: Condition to test.
# ?var2: If the test succeeds.
# :var: If the test fails.
((var=var2>var?var2:var))

traps.body:
# Clear screen on script exit.
trap 'printf \\e[2J\\e[H\\e[m' EXIT

# Call a function on window resize.
trap 'code_here' SIGWINCH

traps.description: Do something when a shell function or a sourced file finishes executing

internal variables.body:

"${FUNCNAME[0]}"

# Parent function.
"${FUNCNAME[1]}"

# So on and so forth.
"${FUNCNAME[2]}"
"${FUNCNAME[3]}"

# All functions including parents.
"${FUNCNAME[@]}"

internal variables.body:

# NOTE: This variable may be empty.

"\${HOSTNAME:-$(hostname)}"

information about the terminal.body:
get_term_size() {
    # Usage: get_term_size

    # (:;:) is a micro sleep to ensure the variables are
    # exported immediately.
    shopt -s checkwinsize; (:;:)
    printf '%s\n' "\$LINES \$COLUMNS"
}
information about the terminal.description: Get the terminal size in lines and columns (*from a script*)
Get the terminal size in pixels

conversion.description: Convert a hex color to RGB
Convert an RGB color to hex

code golf.body:
# Tiny C Style.
for((;i++<10;)){ echo "\$i";}

# Undocumented method.
for i in {1..10};{ echo "\$i";}

# Expansion.
for i in {1..10}; do echo "\$i"; done

# C Style.
for((i=0;i<=10;i++)); do echo "\$i"; done

# Normal method
while :; do echo hi; done

# Shorter
for((;;)){ echo hi;}

# Normal method
f(){ echo hi;}

# Using a subshell
f()(echo hi)

# Using arithmetic
# This can be used to assign integer values.
# Example: f a=1
#          f a++
f()((\$1))

# Using tests, loops etc.
# NOTE: ‘while’, ‘until’, ‘case’, ‘(())’, ‘[[]]’ can also be used.
f()if true; then echo "\$1"; fi
f()for i in "$@"; do echo "\$i"; done

# One line
# Note: The 3rd statement may run when the 1st is true
[[ \$var == hello ]] && echo hi || echo bye
[[ \$var == hello ]] && { echo hi; echo there; } || echo bye

# Multi line (no else, single statement)
# Note: The exit status may not be the same as with an if statement
[[ \$var == hello ]] &&
    echo hi

# Multi line (no else)
[[ \$var == hello ]] && {
    echo hi
    # ...
}

# Modified snippet from Neofetch.
case "\$OSTYPE" in
    "darwin"*)
        : "MacOS"
    ;;

    "linux"*)
        : "Linux"
    ;;

    *"bsd"* | "dragonfly" | "bitrig")
        : "BSD"
    ;;

    "cygwin" | "msys" | "win32")
        : "Windows"
    ;;

    *)
        printf '%s\n' "Unknown OS detected, aborting..." >&2
        exit 1
    ;;
esac

# Finally, set the variable.
os="\$_"

other.description: Use `read` as an alternative to the `sleep` command

other.body:
# There are 3 ways to do this and either one can be used.
type -p executable_name &>/dev/null
hash executable_name &>/dev/null
command -v executable_name &>/dev/null

# As a test.
if type -p executable_name &>/dev/null; then
    # Program is in PATH.
fi

# Inverse.
if ! type -p executable_name &>/dev/null; then
    # Program is not in PATH.
fi

# Example (Exit early if program is not installed).
if ! type -p convert &>/dev/null; then
    printf '%s\n' "error: convert is not installed, exiting..."
    exit 1
fi
other.description: Check if a program is in the user's PATH

other.body:
$ : \\u
# Expand the parameter as if it were a prompt string.
$ printf '%s\n' "${_@P}"
other.description: Get the username of the current user

other.body:
bar() {
    # Usage: bar 1 10
    #            ^----- Elapsed Percentage (0-100).
    #               ^-- Total length in chars.
    ((elapsed=\$1*\$2/100))

    # Create the bar with spaces.
    printf -v prog  "%\${elapsed}s"
    printf -v total "%$((\$2-elapsed))s"

    printf '%s\r' "[${prog// /-}\${total}]"
}

other.description: Get the list of functions in a script
Run a command in the background
Capture the return value of a function without command substitution
